caption: Figure 1: Comparison between the causal models assumed by CEVAE, TEDVAE, and CiVAE.
description: This figure compares the causal models assumed by three different methods for causal effect estimation: CEVAE, TEDVAE, and CiVAE.  Each subfigure illustrates a structural causal model (SCM) showing the relationships between observed variables (X, T, Y) and latent variables (confounders C, post-treatment variables M, instrumental variables I, and adjusters A).  The differences highlight how each method handles confounders and post-treatment variables, showcasing the key assumptions made by each approach. CiVAE's model explicitly distinguishes between latent confounders and latent post-treatment variables, addressing limitations in the other approaches.

caption: Figure 2: Visualization of p-value of independence test before and after conditioning on treatment T.
description: This figure visualizes the results of independence tests performed before and after conditioning on the treatment variable (T). It shows three cases: Intra-Confounder, Intra-Mediator, and Confounder-Mediator. Each case is represented by a heatmap where the color intensity represents the p-value, illustrating the change in dependence between pairs of latent variables before and after conditioning on T.  This visualization helps to differentiate between latent confounders and latent post-treatment variables by their dependence behavior when conditioning on T.

caption: Figure 2: Visualization of p-value of independence test before and after conditioning on treatment T.
description: This figure visualizes the p-values obtained from independence tests performed before and after conditioning on the treatment variable (T).  The tests assess the independence between pairs of latent variables inferred by the CiVAE model. By comparing p-values before and after conditioning on T, the figure helps to distinguish between latent confounders, latent mediators, and the relationship between them, aiding in the identification of true confounders.
